prompt: Please use Image 1 as the base map to generate a pixel map for RPG Maker production. Embellish the image details and replace the forest tile materials and overall style with a more dark fantasy style (art style reference: "{argument name="reference game" default="Elden Ring"}" / "{argument name="reference game 2" default="Dark Souls"}"). Do not enlarge, shrink, or stretch the generated map; please leave any extra areas blank.
title: Image-to-Image Workflow for RPG Maker Pixel Maps using Nano Banana
description: A detailed, multi-step workflow guide for using Nano Banana (specifically Nano Banana 2 or Pro) in image-to-image mode to generate assets like RPG Maker pixel maps or knowledge graphs. It emphasizes using reference images (like RM tiles or game screenshots) to maintain style consistency and provides a sample prompt for generating a dark fantasy RPG map.
author: youmind-library

The prompt emphasizes strong backlighting to create a silhouette effect, deep focus, and a monumental, quiet mood with golden tones and 16K realism.
author: youmind-library

prompt: I tried to create a cute and realistic-looking girl, and initially generated it with only instructions like â€œ{argument name="initial instruction" default="beautiful Japanese woman"},â€ but the AI look inevitably remained like in the first image.... So, I tested what would happen if I restructured the prompt, focusing on a subject image that the AI could easily understand, rather than just atmosphere!
title: Nano Banana Pro Prompt for Realistic Japanese Female Character
description: A prompt designed for Nano Banana Pro to generate a cute and realistic Japanese female character, focusing on specific, AI-understandable attributes rather than vague atmospheric descriptions like 'beautiful Japanese woman,' which often results in an 'AI look.' The successful prompt is shared in the thread.
author: youmind-library

prompt:
I started with two reference images and a simple first prompt:
" Change the clothes of the woman to the {argument name="new outfit" default="yellow and green outfit"}, keep her face the same" 

Once I had that result, I reused the generated image as the new base. 
I added a fresh outfit reference and kept the prompt structure identical, only changing the outfit name:

"Change outfit to [NAME] outfit"
title: Outfit Swapping Workflow with Reference Images
description: A description of a workflow using Gemini 3 and Nano Banana Pro to maintain character identity while iteratively swapping outfits. The initial prompt changes the clothing based on a reference image, and subsequent iterations use the newly generated image as the base for further outfit changes.
